answers.answerText: B. Cupping of the optic nerve

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/neuro21-4.webp)

![](/content/media/neuro21-5.webp)

The horizontal and vertical B-scans on the RNFL OCT demonstrate abnormal areas of traction at the optic nerve head between the vitreous and the nerve (purple arrows). The RNFL thicknesses are normal but asymmetric, and no optic disc cupping is noted on optic nerve head analysis.

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What pathology is seen on the OCT RNFL?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
A 5-line Raster OCT of the optic nerve heads were conducted and shown below:

![](/content/media/neuro21-6.webp)

![](/content/media/neuro21-7.webp)

What disease process is seen on the above OCT images?

answers.explanation:
Vitreopapillary traction is a manifestation of anomalous posterior vitreous detachment at the optic nerve head, which can lead to optic disc elevation and transient relative afferent pupillary defect. It should remain the differential for asymptomatic optic disc edema. The red arrows below demonstrate vitreopapillary traction on the nasal part of the optic discs leading to elevation in that area. 

![](/content/media/neuro21-8.webp)

![](/content/media/neuro21-9.webp)

References: 

1. Hedges TR, Flattem NL, Bagga A. Vitreopapillary traction confirmed by optical coherence tomography. JAMA Ophthalmol 2006;124(2):279-281.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text:
Following conservative management, the patient returned for a 6-month follow-up. Her fundus photo of the right eye (shown below) demonstrated marked improvement of the blurred nasal disc margin. This change was also appreciated in the left eye. 

![](/content/media/neuro21-10.webp)

The HD Cross OCT over the optic nerve OD at the 6-month follow-up is shown below:

![](/content/media/neuro21-11.webp)

What is the key difference in this follow-up OCT macula image compared to initial presentation?

answers.explanation:
The OCT macula on initial presentation demonstrated marked optic nerve head elevation (red arrow); however, with time, the posterior vitreous face slowly detaches off of the neurosensory retina and optic nerve head (blue arrow). This slow process ultimately leads to reduction in optic disc edema.

title: Case 21
description: 23F referred for blurred optic disc margins OU
patientPresentation:
A 23-year-old female was referred to a neuro-ophthalmology clinic for possible optic disc edema. Her past medical history was significant for obesity. Visual acuity was 20/25 OD and 20/30 OS with equal pupil sizes and no RAPD. Colour vision was 14/14 on Ishihara plates OU. Fundus photos and Humphrey 24-2 SITA-fast visual fields are shown below: 

![](/content/media/neuro21-1.webp)

There are indistinct nasal optic disc margins in both eyes.

![](/content/media/neuro21-2.webp)

Visual fields show non-specific depressed points in both eyes.
An OCT RNFL was performed below:

![](/content/media/neuro21-3.webp)
